Knowledge Point: Theoretically it is possible, and grammatically correct, to have a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} like the one in \REF{ex:4:x392}, but natural language data seldom has any \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s with more than two modifiers. Example \REF{ex:4:x393} is one of those.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The only modifier in a noun phrase is most typically either a possessor \REF{ex:4:x395}, a deictic \REF{ex:4:x396} or a qualifying noun or noun phrase. The qualifying noun in \REF{ex:4:x397} is a compound noun.
Content 1: \gll ona siowa | \gls 3s.GEN dog | \glt `his/her dog'
Content 2: \gll ifa nain | \gls snake that1 | \glt `the/that snake'
Content 3: \gll owow(a) maneka mua | \gls village big man | \glt `townsman'

Knowledge Point: An \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{unmarked third person plural pronoun}} is used as an optional plural marking for humans and other human-like beings in \REF{ex:4:x398} and \REF{ex:4:x1831}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wi} sawur=ke kuura puuk-a-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM spirit=CF fly change.into-PA-1/3p | \glt `The spirits changed into flies.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The plural-marking pronoun differs from the appositive use \REF{ex:4:x399} of the unmarked pronoun in that the former is unstressed, whereas the latter is stressed. Furthermore, the appositive use is not restricted to the third person plural pronoun. (For appositional \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s, see \sectref{sec:4.1.4}.)
Content 1: \gll \textbf{'}\textbf{Yo} nena niawi=ke nefa maak-i-yem. | \gls 1s.UNM 2s.GEN 2s/p.father=CF 2s.ACC tell-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I, your father, tell you...'

Knowledge Point: A special case of the plural-marking unmarked pronoun is its occurrence in connection with a place name to refer to the people of that place \REF{ex:4:x400}. The head noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mua} `men, people' or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{emeria} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mua} `people' is not needed. It may be used, but is usually left out.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wi} Lasen=ke ekap-e--mik. | \gls 1p.UNM Lasen=CF come-PA-1/3p | \glt `The Lasen (village) people came.'

Knowledge Point: A \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{temporal phrase}} is rare as a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} constituent. It is mainly the temporal words \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aakis} 'present-day' from \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aakisa} 'now, today' \REF{ex:4:x401} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iiriw} 'earlier' \REF{ex:4:x1883} that are used. A temporal phrase is also allowed but uncommon.
Content 1: \gll ni \textbf{aakis} takira | \gls 2p.UNM present-day young.person | \glt `you young people of today'
Content 2: \gll wi \textbf{iiriw} \textbf{akena} mua | \gls 3p.UNM earlier truly man | \glt `the people of long ago'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{possessive} }\textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textup{np}} can only be [+human], with `human' including spirits \REF{ex:4:x402} and sometimes some domestic animals like dogs or pigs \REF{ex:4:x403}. The humanness of the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{possnp} is stressed by the fact that it may be followed by a pronoun copy in the genitive \REF{ex:4:x402}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{sawur} \textbf{emeria} ona onak wiawi | \gls spirit woman 3s.GEN 3s/p.mother 3s/p.father | \glt `the spirit woman's parents'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{siowa} wiawi | \gls dog 3s/p.father | \glt `the dog's owner'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{sawur} \textbf{emeria} ona onak wiawi | \gls spirit woman 3s.GEN 3s/p.mother 3s/p.father | \glt `the spirit woman's parents'

Knowledge Point: The head noun of the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{possnp} may itself be possessed \REF{ex:4:x404}, \REF{ex:4:x405}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{yiena} \textbf{kae} sira | \gls 1p.GEN 1s/p.grandfather custom | \glt `our ancestors' (lit: grandfathers') custom'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The semantic relation of the ``possessor'' to the ``possessed'' may be that of real ownership, paraphrasable with `have' \REF{ex:4:x406}, a human relationship \REF{ex:4:x402}, origin \REF{ex:4:x404} or subjecthood \REF{ex:4:x407}.
Content 1: \gll ona koora | \gls 3s.GEN house | \glt `his house'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{sawur} \textbf{emeria} ona onak wiawi | \gls spirit woman 3s.GEN 3s/p.mother 3s/p.father | \glt `the spirit woman's parents'
Content 4: \gll takira niir-owa | \gls youth play-NMZ | \glt `young people's play(ing)'

Knowledge Point: Either an unmarked pronoun or a genitive pronoun may be used as a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{possessive pronoun}} \REF{ex:4:x409}. Often the two can be used interchangeably, but the following rules and tendencies have been observed. First, when the pronoun is a pronoun copy of a preceding possessive \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, it must be in the genitive \REF{ex:4:x410}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ona} apura maa oposia me enim-i-non. | \gls 3s.GEN widow thing meat not eat-Np-FU.3s | \glt `His widow will not eat meat.'
Content 2: \gll sawur emeria \textbf{ona} onak wiawi | \gls spirit woman 3s.GEN 3s/p.mother 3s/p.father | \glt `the spirit woman's parents'

Knowledge Point: Second, an unmarked pronoun is used especially with things that are closely related to a person \REF{ex:4:x1315}, whereas the genitive pronoun tends to be used more when the ownership is emphasized \REF{ex:4:x1314}.
Content 1: \gll Oo, \textbf{no} \textbf{emeria} iiriw sesek-a-mik. | \gls Oh 2s.UNM woman already send-PA-1/3p | \glt `Oh, we already sent your wife away.'
Content 2: \gll Nep(a) opaimika me amis(a)-ar-ep \textbf{wiena} \textbf{opaimik(a)}\textbf{=iw} yia maak-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls bird talk not knowledge-INCH-SS.SEQ 3p.GEN talk=INST 1p.ACC tell-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They did not know Tok Pisin and talked to us in their (own) language.'

Knowledge Point: Third, an unmarked pronoun used possessively often receives extra stress in speech \REF{ex:4:x408}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In recursive genitive structures like \REF{ex:4:x405}, more than one possessive pronoun may occur as a pronoun copy, so \REF{ex:4:x411} is a possible alternative for \REF{ex:4:x405}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll i emeria apura \textbf{yiena} mua weria \textbf{wiena} emeria nain=ke | \gls 1p.UNM woman widow 1p.GEN man planting.stick 3p.GEN woman that1=CF | \glt `the wives of the ``weria-relatives'' of us widows'

Knowledge Point: A \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{qualifying noun phrase}} usually consists of the head noun only \REF{ex:4:x413}--\REF{ex:4:x1832}. If it has other elements, the structure is that of the basic noun phrase. The distinction between a qualifying \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} and a possessive \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} on the one hand, and between a qualifying \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} and a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{n+n} compound on the other, is often hard to make. (See \sectref{sec:3.2.5} for a discussion on the distinction between compound nouns and \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s.) Unlike a possessive \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, a qualifying \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} may not take a genitive pronoun copy.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Fiker(a)} epia nain aw-i-non. | \gls kunai.grass fire that1 burn-Np-FU.3s | \glt `The grass fire will burn.'
Content 2: \gll Epa kokom-ar-eya urera \textbf{siowa} mua ookinon. | \gls place dark-INCH-2/3s.DS afternoon dog man follow-Np-FU.3s | \glt `When it gets dark in the afternoon he will follow the ``dog man'' (a certain nominated person in the singsing traditions).'

Knowledge Point: A place name may be a qualifier for a locative noun functioning as head noun \REF{ex:4:x834}, \REF{ex:4:x833}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Bogia} era | \gls Bogia road | \glt `the Bogia road'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Malala} owowa | \gls Malala village | \glt `Malala village'

Knowledge Point: The qualifying \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} can also be a nominalized clause. This is most common when the head noun is an abstract noun like \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{sira} `custom' \REF{ex:4:x414} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{opora} `talk, story'.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{garanga} \textbf{oko} \textbf{muuka} \textbf{wiar} \textbf{aaw-owa}\textsubscript{NP} sira | \gls family other son 3.DAT get-NMZ custom | \glt `adoption custom (lit: the custom of getting a son from another family)'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{head noun}} is either a single or a compound noun. If the head noun is replaced by a pronoun, it can only take post-modifiers \REF{ex:4:x415}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{wi(am)} arow nain | \gls 3p.UNM(REFL) three that1 | \glt `the three of them / those three'

Knowledge Point: A \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{post-modifying noun phrase}} often expresses qualities that in many European languages would be expressed by true adjectives \REF{ex:4:x416}, or via adjectivalized \REF{ex:4:x417} or comitative expressions \REF{ex:4:x418}.
Content 1: \gll labuel(a) \textbf{mua} | \gls pawpaw man | \glt `male pawpaw'
Content 2: \gll takira \textbf{emin(a)} \textbf{kekanowa} | \gls boy occiput strong | \glt `pig-headed boy'
Content 3: \gll mua \textbf{bug} \textbf{maala} nain | \gls man wind long that1 | \glt `the man with good lungs'

Knowledge Point: A noun phrase can have one or more \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{adjective phrases}} as modifiers. The adjective phrase typically consists of an adjective only. If there are more \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{ap}s} than one, the order is as follows: colour - physical property or human propensity - size/age - value \REF{ex:4:x419}.
Content 1: \gll Waa(ya) muuka \textbf{kia} \textbf{gelemuta} op-a-m. | \gls pig son white small catch-PA-1s | \glt `I caught a small white piglet.'

Knowledge Point: In recorded texts the maximum number of adjective phrases per \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} is two, but the speakers have no difficulty producing \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s with more \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{ap}}s \REF{ex:4:x420}:
Content 1: \gll Emer(a) \textbf{itita} \textbf{enum(a)} \textbf{eliwa} nain enak-e. | \gls sago soft new good that1 feed.me-IMP.2s | \glt `Give me the good new soft sago/bread to eat.'

Knowledge Point: The position of either a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{quantifier phrase}} or an \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{indefinite}} is after the adjective phrase \REF{ex:4:x804}.
Content 1: \gll Siowa morena \textbf{oko} aruf-a-k. | \gls dog male another hit-PA-3s | \glt `He hit another male dog.'

Knowledge Point: The last regular post-modifier in a noun phrase is a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{demonstrative}}. Especially the distal demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' is very common \REF{ex:4:x805}, and in many cases it is no more than a marker for given information.
Content 1: \gll koora erepam \textbf{nain} | \gls house four that1 | \glt `the/those four houses' or `the fourth house'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{dative pronoun}} (\sectref{sec:3.5.5}) is unusual as a modifier. Semantically, it belongs to the noun phrase, marking a possessive relationship, but syntactically it still reflects its origin as a [+human] locative adverbial (\sectref{sec:4.6.1}) of the verb. It is often non-contiguous with the rest of the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, which can be fronted for a theme while the dative pronoun needs to stay in its pre-verbal position \REF{ex:4:x1811}. Other elements that can separate the dative pronoun from the rest of the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} are \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} `not' \REF{ex:4:x1812}, and the free adverbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muutiw} `only' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pun} `also' \REF{ex:4:x1938}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pina} \textbf{gelemuta} eliw owowa=pa \textbf{nefar} kaken-ami welaw-i-kuan. | \gls guilt small well village=LOC 2s.DAT straighten-SS.SIM finish-Np-FU.3p | \glt `Your small guilt they can well straighten and finish in the village.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Amina} \textbf{fain} me \textbf{wiar} op-aka. | \gls pot this not 3.DAT hold-IMP.2p | \glt `Don't hold/touch these pots of hers.'
Content 3: \gll Yo miira me uruf-a-m, \textbf{afifa} muutiw \textbf{wiar} uruf-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM face not see-PA-1s hair only 3.DAT see-PA-1s | \glt `I didn't see the face, I only saw his hair.'

Knowledge Point: Joining noun phrases into a coordinate noun phrase can be done either by simple juxtaposition or with connectives. Juxtaposition is the default strategy \REF{ex:4:x810}, \REF{ex:4:x811}. In spoken texts the juxtaposed noun phrases are separated by a longer pause, in written texts by a comma.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Amina}, \textbf{wiowa}, \textbf{eka} \textbf{napia} koor miira=pa iimar-ow-a-mik. | \gls pot spear, water bamboo house face=LOC stand-CAUS-PA-1/3p | \glt `We placed the pots, spears and water bamboos in front of the house.'
Content 2: \gll I \textbf{mua} \textbf{unowa}, \textbf{emeria} \textbf{papako} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 1s.UNM man many woman some go-PA-1/3p | \glt `Many men (including the narrator) and some women went.'

Knowledge Point: The pragmatic connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} `additive' (\sectref{sec:3.11.1}) is used rather infrequently to connect the parts of a coordinate noun phrase \REF{ex:4:x812}. When it is used, and when there are more than two noun phrases to connect, it is usually placed between the last two noun phrases \REF{ex:4:x814}, but other positions are possible too, see (3.\ref{ex:3:x1359}).
Content 1: \gll Nie \textbf{ne} neke nomokow fiira=ke. | \gls 2s/p.maternal.uncle ADD 2s/p.grandfather tree root=CF | \glt `Your maternal uncle and your grandfather are the most important relatives.'
Content 2: \gll Mera kas, mulamul \textbf{ne} popotimaw aaw-i-mik. | \gls fish mackerel trevally.sp ADD trevally.sp get-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `We catch mackerel, \textstyleForeignWords{mulamul} trevally and \textstyleForeignWords{popotimaw} trevally.'
Content 3: \gll Sesa nain waaya erup arow \textbf{ne} maamuma kuuma erepam ikur \textbf{ne} manar kuisow, waa eneka, naap muuka sesenar-i-nen. | \gls price that1 pig two three ADD money stick four five ADD forehead.ornament one pig tooth thus son buy-Np-FU.1s | \glt `(As for) the price, I will buy my son with two-three pigs and forty-fifty kina and a forehead ornament (and) pig's tusk(s), like that.'

Knowledge Point: A focus clitic \REF{ex:4:x893} or a case marking clitic \REF{ex:4:x894} is only added to the last noun phrase in a coordinate noun phrase.
Content 1: \gll Manin koora nain \textbf{koka} \textbf{ne} \textbf{ifara=ke} wakesim-o-k. | \gls garden house that1 jungle ADD vine=CF cover-PA-3s | \glt `The garden house was covered by jungle and vines.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wiena} \textbf{merena} \textbf{ne} \textbf{wapen=iw} era akup-a-mik. | \gls 3p.GEN foot ADD hand=INST road search-PA-1/3p | \glt `They felt (lit: searched) for the road with their feet and hands.'

Knowledge Point: The pragmatic connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aria} `alright', too, can occasionally join the elements of a coordinate noun phrase \REF{ex:4:x815}, \REF{ex:4:x816}. As a sentential or clausal connective it indicates a break in the discourse, but when it joins two noun phrases there does not seem to be a significant difference between that and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} `additive.' It may be that \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aria} draws more attention to the separate noun phrases being joined than either juxtaposition or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} does.
Content 1: \gll Yos, yena auwa, \textbf{aria} wi emer en-ow(a) mua kuisow ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 1s.FC 1s.GEN 1s/p.father alright 3p.UNM sago eat-NMZ man one go-PA-1/3p | \glt `I, my father, and one Sepik man went.'
Content 2: \gll Moma, \textbf{aria} emera naap lawisiw eeyar-e-k. | \gls taro, alright sago thus rather last-PA-3s | \glt `Taro, and sago, lasted a little (longer).'

Knowledge Point: The disjunctive connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e} `or' \REF{ex:4:x817} (\sectref{sec:3.11.2}), and/or the question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} \REF{ex:4:x818} is used in a coordinate noun phrase if the noun phrases are presented as alternatives.
Content 1: \gll Mera aaw-owa sira \textbf{e} era ikur okaiwi=pa kuisow ik-ua. | \gls fish get-NMZ custom or way five other.side=LOC one be-PA.3s | \glt `There are six means, or ways, of catching fish.'
Content 2: \gll Maa oposia\textbf{=i} moma, emera, naap sesek-a-mik. | \gls thing meat=QM taro sago thus sell-PA-1/3p | \glt `They sold meat, or taro, (or) sago, (things) like that.'

Knowledge Point: A comitative noun phrase is made up of one or two basic noun phrases plus a comitative postposition or clitic (\sectref{sec:3.12.1}). A comitative pronoun (\sectref{sec:3.5.9}) can also form a comitative phrase either by itself or attached to a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} \REF{ex:4:x828}--\REF{ex:4:x830}. When there is only one overt noun phrase and if it is unmarked for number, the plurality is shown both by the comitative marking and in the verb person marking \REF{ex:4:x819}. The choice of the comitative marker and the number marking in the verb, when relevant, reflect whether the noun phrases in the comitative relationship are co-subjects/co-objects of the same verb \REF{ex:4:x832}, or whether one is a dominant member \REF{ex:4:x831}.
Content 1: \gll Ikoka \textbf{mua} \textbf{owawiya} irak-ep me efar kerer-e. | \gls later man with fight-SS.SEQ not 1s.DAT appear-IMP.2s | \glt `Later when you fight with your husband, do not come to me.'
Content 2: \gll Parosifa siisim-ep \textbf{muuka} \textbf{feekiya} sesek-i-nen. | \gls letter write-SS.SEQ son with send-Np-FU.1s | \glt `I will write a letter and send it with my son.'
Content 4: \gll Rabaul kemena=pa naap pok-ap ik-e-mik, \textbf{mua=iya} \textbf{emeria}. | \gls Rabaul bay=LOC thus sit-SS.SEQ be-PA-1/3p man=COM woman | \glt `They are now sitting in the Rabaul bay, the husband and/with the wife.'
Content 5: \gll \textbf{Wiamiya} irak-owa na-ep ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 3p.COM fight-NMZ say-SS.SEQ go-PA-1/3p | \glt `We went to fight with them.'

Knowledge Point: With the dual comitative postposition \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikos} there may be an additive connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} between the two noun phrases \REF{ex:4:x820}. It seems to be more common with younger speakers.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Osaiwa} \textbf{ne} \textbf{aalbok} \textbf{ikos} womar wiam op-a-mik. | \gls bird.of.paradise ADD black.cuckoo.shrike with 3s/p.friend 3p.REFL hold-PA-1/3p | \glt `The bird of paradise and/with the black cuckoo-shrike were friends.'

Knowledge Point: An appositional noun phrase consists of two noun phrases which have identical or similar reference \citep[24]{Crystal1997}. Very commonly, the first noun phrase is either a personal pronoun \REF{ex:4:x835} or a kinship term \REF{ex:4:x836}, \REF{ex:4:x839}, the second one a proper name, but there are other possibilities as well \REF{ex:4:x837}, \REF{ex:4:x838}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yo} \textbf{nena} \textbf{nie=ke} nefa maak-i-yem. | \gls 1s.UNM 2s.GEN 2s/p.uncle 2s.ACC tell-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I, your uncle, am telling you this.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Yena} \textbf{yaiya} \textbf{Tup} ifa=ke keraw-a-k. | \gls 1s.GEN 1s/p.uncle Tup snake=CF bite-PA-3s | \glt `My Uncle Tup was bitten by a snake.'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Inasina} \textbf{Rubaruba} \textbf{nain=ke} ona emeria aaw-ep p-ikiw-o-k. | \gls spirit Rubaruba that1=CF 3s.GEN woman take-SS.SEQ BPX-go-PA-3s | \glt `The spirit Rubaruba took his wife and went.'
Content 5: \gll \textbf{Manina} \textbf{gelemuta,} \textbf{esewa,} nena kookal-owa=pa perek-i-nan. | \gls garden small esewa 2s.GEN like-NMZ=LOC pull.out-Np-FU.2s | \glt `You may harvest the little garden, ``esewa'', at your desire.'

Knowledge Point: The head of an adjective phrase (\textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{ap}}) is an adjective. Most commonly it occurs alone, but it can be intensified by an intensity adverb either preceding or following it, or both \REF{ex:4:x841}. The negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{marew} `none, no' when following the adjective, negates its quality, thus creating its opposite \REF{ex:4:x842}.
Content 1: \gll Owowa nain \textbf{lawiliw} \textbf{manek(a)} \textbf{akena}. | \gls village that1 rather big very | \glt `The village is rather big'
Content 2: \gll Koora \textbf{eliw(a)} \textbf{marew} nan ik-e-mik. | \gls house good none there be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They live in the bad (lit: no-good) house.'

Knowledge Point: When the adjective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{masia} `bitter' takes a nominalized verb as its modifier, the meaning of the adjective changes to indicate that one is doing a lot of some action \REF{ex:4:x840}.
Content 1: \gll Mua \textbf{manin(a)} \textbf{mauw-ow(a)} \textbf{masia} nain emeria wi-i-mik. | \gls man garden work-NMZ compulsive that1 woman give.him-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `We give a wife to a hard-working man.'

Knowledge Point: The adjective phrase functions as a post-modifier in a noun phrase \REF{ex:4:x842}, or as a non-verbal predicate \REF{ex:4:x841}.
Content 1: \gll Koora \textbf{eliw(a)} \textbf{marew} nan ik-e-mik. | \gls house good none there be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They live in the bad (lit: no-good) house.'
Content 2: \gll Owowa nain \textbf{lawiliw} \textbf{manek(a)} \textbf{akena}. | \gls village that1 rather big very | \glt `The village is rather big'

Knowledge Point: A coordinate adjective phrase is also possible \REF{ex:4:x891}. The additive \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} is used instead of juxtaposition.
Content 1: \gll Oka keraw-a-k nain \textbf{efefa} \textbf{ne} \textbf{eliwa} \textbf{akena}. | \gls hand.drum carve-PA-3s that1 light ADD good very | \glt `The hand drum that he carved is light and very good.'

Knowledge Point: A quantifier phrase (\textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{qp}}) usually only consists of a quantifier head \REF{ex:4:x845} (\sectref{sec:3.4}), but it can be modified by a few intensity adverbs \REF{ex:4:x844} (\sectref{sec:3.9.2}).
Content 1: \gll I koora \textbf{kuisow} yiar aw-o-k. | \gls 1p.UNM house one 1p.DAT burn-PA-3s | \glt `One of our houses burned.'
Content 2: \gll Koora \textbf{arow} \textbf{akena} ku-a-mik. | \gls house three truly build-PA-1/3p | \glt `We built exactly three houses.'

Knowledge Point: A quantifier phrase most commonly functions as a post-modifier in a noun phrase \REF{ex:4:x846}, but it can also be used as a non-verbal predicate \REF{ex:4:x843}.
Content 1: \gll Maamuma \textbf{unowa} \textbf{akena} aaw-e-mik. | \gls money much truly/very get-PA-1/3p | \glt `They got very much money.'
Content 2: \gll Yo muuka \textbf{arow}. | \gls 1s.UNM son three. | \glt `I have three sons.' (Lit: `My sons are three.)

Knowledge Point: Quantifier phrases may also be coordinated. The most plausible coordination semantically is disjunction \REF{ex:4:x1360}:
Content 1: \gll Waaya maneka wiowa \textbf{erup-i} \textbf{e} \textbf{arow} naap mik-iwkin um-i-ya. | \gls pig big spear two=QM or three thus spear-2/3p.DS die-Np-PR.3s | \glt `They spear a big pig with two or three spears and it dies.'

Knowledge Point: The possessive phrase\footnote{Not to be confused with the Possessive NP.} is a very specific and rare structure \REF{ex:4:x847}. It consists of an unmarked or genitive pronoun, followed by the long form of the dative pronoun (\sectref{sec:3.5.5}), which has developed from the dative pronoun and the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be'. The verb has lost all inflection and only retains the root, which has merged into the dative pronoun. The possessive phrase only functions as a non-verbal predicate. It is always without a head noun. A co-referential noun or pronoun is encoded in an earlier \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} in the same clause.
Content 1: \gll Auwa maa unowa nain pun \textbf{yo/yena} \textbf{efarik}. | \gls father thing many that1 also 1s.UNM/1s.GEN 1s.DAT | \glt `My father's possessions, too, are mine.'

Knowledge Point: Every transitive verb requires an accusative pronoun for a [+human] object, regardless of whether there is an object noun phrase or not \REF{ex:4:x848}--\REF{ex:4:x850}. The accusative pronoun is also required, when the verb is in benefactive form and the beneficiary is plural \REF{ex:4:x851}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Yaapan=ke i emeria \textbf{yia} \textbf{aaw-urum-i-kuan}. | \gls Japan=CF 1p.UNM woman 1p.ACC take-DISTR/A-Np-FU.3p | \glt `Japan will take all of us women.'
Content 3: \gll Takira enow gelemuta \textbf{wia} \textbf{on-om-a-mik}. | \gls child meal small 3p.ACC make-BEN-BNFY2-PA-1/3p | \glt `We made a feast for the children.'

Knowledge Point: The locative adverbs (\sectref{sec:3.6.3}), all of which are deictic, occur by themselves, without modifiers \REF{ex:4:x870}--\REF{ex:4:x1833}. The same form can be used for location, source, or goal, depending on the verb.
Content 1: \gll Miiw-aasa \textbf{nan} ik-eya mua nain nabena suuw-a-mik. | \gls land-canoe there be-2/3s.DS man that1 carrying.pole push-PA-1/3p | \glt `The car stayed there, and they carried the man on their shoulders.'
Content 2: \gll Manin(a) onoma maa en-owa \textbf{nan} aaw-i-ya. | \gls garden basis thing eat-NMZ there get-Np-PR.3s | \glt `An owner of a garden (lit: the garden basis) gets his food from there.'

Knowledge Point: When the locative phrase is based on a noun phrase, one form is used both for a location where something takes place and a source, but a goal is marked differently. The phrases indicating a location are formed by adding the locative clitic \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa} to a noun phrase \REF{ex:4:x856}--\REF{ex:4:x865}.
Content 1: \gll Pon \textbf{sisina=pa} ik-eya mik-a-m. | \gls turtle shallow.water=LOC be-2/3s.DS spear-PA-1s | \glt `The turtle was in shallow water and I speared it.'
Content 2: \gll Nomokowa unowa serer-iw-ap \textbf{Takora=pa} \textbf{nan} or-o-mik. | \gls tree many hang-go-SS.SEQ Takora=LOC there descend-PA-1/3p | \glt `They went hanging to many trees, and at Takora they got down.'

Knowledge Point: Source is also marked as a location, with the clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa} \REF{ex:4:x858}--\REF{ex:4:x864}. In some cases there is possible ambiguity as to the interpretation, but the context usually provides a clue.
Content 1: \gll Parosifa siisim-ep \textbf{iinan} \textbf{aasa=pa} wafur-a-mik. | \gls paper write-SS.SEQ sky canoe=LOC throw-PA-1/3p | \glt `They wrote papers and threw them from airplanes.'
Content 2: \gll Me fan \textbf{Madang} \textbf{kame=pa} ekap-e-mik. | \gls not here Madang side=LOC come-PA-1/3p | \glt `They didn't come here from the Madang side.'

Knowledge Point: The noun phrase indicating a goal normally does not take the locative clitic or any other marking. The directional verbs are the most common ones used with goal \REF{ex:4:x860}, \REF{ex:4:x861}, but other verbs of motion can be used as well \REF{ex:4:x862}, \REF{ex:4:x863}.
Content 1: \gll Ae, o \textbf{fiker} \textbf{gone} urup-o-k. | \gls yes 3s.UNM kunai.grass middle ascend-PA-3s | \glt `Yes, he went up to the middle of the \textstyleForeignWords{kunai} grass area.'
Content 2: \gll Manina=pa nan\textsubscript{Source} \textbf{koka}\textsubscript{Goal} iw-a-mik. | \gls garden=LOC there jungle go-PA-1/3p | \glt `From the garden there the day they went into the jungle.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Medebur} karu-eka, baurar-eka. | \gls Medebur run-IMP.2p flee-IMP.2p | \glt `Run to Medebur, flee!'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Ulingan} \textbf{nan} bom fu-fuurk-ikiw-e-mik. | \gls Ulingan there bomb RDP-throw-go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They went throwing bombs to Ulingan.'

Knowledge Point: It is possible to mark the goal with the locative clitic if the goal is mainly important as the location of the following verb. The frequency of this usage for the clitic is low. Example (3.\ref{ex:3:x1878}) is repeated below as \REF{ex:4:x1884}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: When the locative phrase is [+human], the dative pronoun (\sectref{sec:3.5.5}) must be used \REF{ex:4:x1061}, \REF{ex:4:x1939}.
Content 1: \gll Mua oko=ke waaya nain mik-ap \textbf{nefar} aaw-i-non. | \gls man other=CF pig that1 spear-SS.SEQ 2s.DAT take-Np-FU.3s | \glt `Another man will spear the pig and take it from you.'
Content 2: \gll Feeke \textbf{wiar} ik-ok kiiriw mua \textbf{wiar} urup-e. | \gls here.CF 3.DAT be-SS again man 3.DAT ascend-IMP.2s | \glt `Stay here with him and (then) go (back) to your husband again.'

Knowledge Point: The dative pronoun is also commonly added when the location is a village or a larger area, which is seen mainly as a setting for the people. In both \REF{ex:4:x862} and \REF{ex:4:x863} above it is the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{location}} which is in focus, in the former as the closest village to flee to, and in the latter as an object of bombing, so the dative pronoun is not used. In \REF{ex:4:x1801} a certain culturally important place referred to is in the area of the Koran village people and considered their property:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Medebur} karu-eka, baurar-eka. | \gls Medebur run-IMP.2p flee-IMP.2p | \glt `Run to Medebur, flee!'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ulingan} \textbf{nan} bom fu-fuurk-ikiw-e-mik. | \gls Ulingan there bomb RDP-throw-go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They went throwing bombs to Ulingan.'
Content 3: \gll Koran epa=pa \textbf{wiar} ik-ua. | \gls Koran place=LOC 3.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt `It is in Koran area.'

Knowledge Point: The noun phrase indicating a path is marked with the instrumental clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw} \REF{ex:4:x866}, \REF{ex:4:x867}, or occasionally with the locative clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa} (3.\ref{ex:3:x770}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Iinan=iw} \textbf{iinan=iw} wu-ami feenap {\dots} ikiw-o-k. | \gls on.top=INST on.top=INST putSS.SIM like.this ... go-PA-3s | \glt `They (airplanes) flew (lit: put) high up, high up, and went like this{\dots}'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Saa}\textbf{=iw} ir-am-ika-i-mik, oos ono-onaiya. | \gls sand=INST ascend-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p, horse RDP-with | \glt `They are coming along the beach, with horses.'
Content 3: \gll Saa=\textbf{pa} ir-am-ika-i-mik. | \gls sand=LOC come/go-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They are coming on/along the beach.'

Knowledge Point: When a clause has more locative phrases than one, the following rules apply. If the phrases have a different function, source is placed before goal \REF{ex:4:x861}. When they have the same function and a deictic locative adverb strengthens another locative phrase, the adverb follows the other locative \REF{ex:4:x857}, \REF{ex:4:x863}. But the dative pronoun, when used locatively, has to be placed even after the locative adverb \REF{ex:4:x1939}. When both of the phrases have an independent meaning, the phrase indicating the more general location comes first, and the one marking the more specific location follows \REF{ex:4:x868}, \REF{ex:4:x869}.
Content 1: \gll Manina=pa nan\textsubscript{Source} \textbf{koka}\textsubscript{Goal} iw-a-mik. | \gls garden=LOC there jungle go-PA-1/3p | \glt `From the garden there the day they went into the jungle.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Sapara=pa} \textbf{nan} suusa iw-e-mik. | \gls Sapara=LOC there needle give.him-PA-1/3p | \glt `There in Sapara he was given an injection.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Ulingan} \textbf{nan} bom fu-fuurk-ikiw-e-mik. | \gls Ulingan there bomb RDP-throw-go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They went throwing bombs to Ulingan.'
Content 4: \gll Feeke \textbf{wiar} ik-ok kiiriw mua \textbf{wiar} urup-e. | \gls here.CF 3.DAT be-SS again man 3.DAT ascend-IMP.2s | \glt `Stay here with him and (then) go (back) to your husband again.'
Content 5: \gll Mia aka nain aaw-ep p-ikiw-ep \textbf{manina=pa} \textbf{upuna}\textbf{=pa} wu-a-k. | \gls body blood that1 take-SS.SEQ BPX-go-SS.SEQ garden=LOC row=LOC put-PA-3s | \glt `She took the menstrual blood with her and put it in a (plant) row in a garden.'

Knowledge Point: Temporals mark location in time, so it is natural that temporal phrases behave very similarly to locative phrases. They can consist of a temporal adverb (\sectref{sec:3.9.1.2}), possibly modified by an intensity adverb (\sectref{sec:3.9.2}) or of a noun phrase (\sectref{sec:4.1}) with a head noun indicating time \REF{ex:4:x872}, plus a locative clitic with some nouns \REF{ex:4:x873} (\sectref{sec:3.12.4}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Uuriw} \textbf{akena} mukuna nain kerer-e-k. | \gls morning truly/very fire that1 appear-PA-3s | \glt `The fire started early in the morning.'
Content 2: \gll Ne \textbf{fraide=pa} maapora puk-o-k, \textbf{urera}. | \gls ADD Friday=LOC feast burst-PA-3s afternoon | \glt `And on Friday the feast started, in the afternoon.'

Knowledge Point: Recursion of temporal phrases is possible and quite common. When there are two or more temporal phrases in the same clause, the order is determined by whether the temporals are deictic and/or specific \REF{ex:4:x874}--\REF{ex:4:x876} (\sectref{sec:3.9.1.2}). Their default order relative to each other is as follows:
Content 1: \gll Ne \textbf{nainiw} \textbf{sande} \textbf{uura} yiam fiirim-e-mik. | \gls ADD again Sunday night 1p.REFL gather-PA-1/3p | \glt `And we gathered again on Sunday night.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ikoka} \textbf{trinde}\textbf{=pa} \textbf{nainiw} aakun-i-yen. | \gls later Wednesday=LOC again talk-Np-FU.1p | \glt `We'll talk again later on Wednesday.'

Knowledge Point: The position of the non-deictic non-specific temporal is either as the first \REF{ex:4:x874} or the last element \REF{ex:4:x876} of the group of temporals.
Content 1: \gll Ne \textbf{nainiw} \textbf{sande} \textbf{uura} yiam fiirim-e-mik. | \gls ADD again Sunday night 1p.REFL gather-PA-1/3p | \glt `And we gathered again on Sunday night.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ikoka} \textbf{trinde}\textbf{=pa} \textbf{nainiw} aakun-i-yen. | \gls later Wednesday=LOC again talk-Np-FU.1p | \glt `We'll talk again later on Wednesday.'

Knowledge Point: When a noun phrase acts as a temporal phrase, the locative clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa} is attached to it \REF{ex:4:x876}, unless it is followed by another temporal phrase specifying it further or it includes a demonstrative \REF{ex:4:x875}. If there are several of these temporal noun phrases, their relative order is from the larger time unit to the smaller one \REF{ex:4:x878}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ikoka} \textbf{trinde}\textbf{=pa} \textbf{nainiw} aakun-i-yen. | \gls later Wednesday=LOC again talk-Np-FU.1p | \glt `We'll talk again later on Wednesday.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Uurika} \textbf{mande} \textbf{uuriw} amia mua feeke kerer-i-non. | \gls tomorrow Monday morning bow man here.CF appear-Np-FU.3s | \glt `Tomorrow Monday a policeman will come here in the morning.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Mokoma} \textbf{fain} \textbf{siiwa} \textbf{Mas}\textbf{=pa} weeser-i-non. | \gls year this month March=LOC finish-Np-FU.3s | \glt `It will finish in March this year.'

Knowledge Point: A temporal phrase may be formed with the instrumental clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw} (\sectref{sec:3.12.5}) when something takes place repeatedly at the same time of the day. The example (3.\ref{ex:3:x1882}) is here repeated as \REF{ex:4:x1907}:
Content 1: \gll I amirik=\textbf{iw} ... Gawar wiar ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM daytime=INST ... Gawar 3.DAT go-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the daytime we always went to Gawar {\dots}'
Content 2: \gll I amirik=\textbf{iw} ... Gawar wiar ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM daytime=INST ... Gawar 3.DAT go-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the daytime we (always) went to Gawar {\dots}'

Knowledge Point: An adverbial phrase indicating manner most often consists of just a manner adverb \REF{ex:4:x880} (\sectref{sec:3.9.1.3}). That is occasionally intensified by an intensity adverb \REF{ex:4:x879}, \REF{ex:4:x881}(\sectref{sec:3.9.2}).
Content 1: \gll Iwera nainiw \textbf{kaken} iimar-e-k. | \gls coconut again straight stand.up-PA-3s | \glt `The coconut palm stood up straight again.'
Content 2: \gll Koran wiena \textbf{balisow} \textbf{akena} epa nain amis-ar-e-mik. | \gls Koran 3p.GEN well truly/very place that1 knowledge-INCH-PA-1/3p | \glt `The Koran people themselves know that place very well.'
Content 3: \gll O \textbf{iiwawun} \textbf{samor} aaw-o-k. | \gls 3p.UNM altogether badly get-PA-3s | \glt `He got it really bad (= he got into a very bad condition).'

Knowledge Point: A manner phrase can also be formed by a noun phrase plus a clitic, either instrumental \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw} \REF{ex:4:x882} or, less frequently, with locative -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa} \REF{ex:4:x884}.
Content 1: \gll Siowa wiawi=ke siowa aluowa miim-ap \textbf{karu-(o)w(a)=iw} ekap-o-k. | \gls dog 3s/p.father dog noise hear-SS.SEQ run-NMZ=INST come-PA-3s | \glt `The dog's master heard its noise and came running.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Yiena} \textbf{kae} \textbf{sira=pa} mauw-owa ik-ua. | \gls 1p.GEN grandfather custom=LOC work-NMZ be-PA.3s | \glt `We have to work according to the custom of our grandfathers.'

Knowledge Point: If there are more manner phrases than one, one of them is usually deictic \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus, like that' \REF{ex:4:x883}, or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{feenap} `like this' either preceding or following the other manner phrase(s).
Content 1: \gll Wi Yaapan \textbf{naap} \textbf{kuisow=iw} ekap-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM Japan thus one=INST come-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `The Japanese came like that one by one.'

Knowledge Point: When comparison is indicated in the manner phrase, the postposition \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{saarik} `like, as' follows the noun phrase \REF{ex:4:x885}.
Content 1: \gll Wie, wiawi nain \textbf{ifa} \textbf{saarik} in-urum-ep-ik-e-mik. | \gls 3s/p.uncle 3s/p.father that1 snake like sleep-DISTR/A-SS.SEQ-be-PA-1/3s | \glt `His uncles and fathers were all sleeping like snakes.'

Knowledge Point: One type of a manner phrase is one that indicates instrument. It is always formed with a noun phrase plus one of three clitics: instrumental -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{} (\sectref{sec:3.12.5}), locative -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa} (\sectref{sec:3.12.4})\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{} or comitative -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iya}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{} (\sectref{sec:3.12.1}). The instrumental clitic is the most common \REF{ex:4:x886}, \REF{ex:4:x889}.
Content 1: \gll Ifa mia nain \textbf{fura=iw} lalat-em-ik-om-a-mik. | \gls snake skin that1 knife=INST sweep-SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `They kept scraping the snake skin off her with a knife.'
Content 2: \gll ...\textbf{wiena} \textbf{opaimik=iw} yia maak-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls ...3p.GEN mouth/language=INST 1p.ACC tell-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `{\dots}they kept telling us in their language.'

Knowledge Point: When a coordinate noun phrase is made into an instrumental manner phrase, the instrumental clitic only follows the last noun phrase \REF{ex:4:x892}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wiena} \textbf{merena} \textbf{ne} \textbf{wapen=iw} era akup-amik. | \gls 3p.GEN foot ADD hand=INST way search-PA-1/3p | \glt `With their feet and hands they felt (lit: searched) for the road.'

Knowledge Point: The use of locative clitic is restricted almost exclusively to those cases where the instrument is a vehicle \REF{ex:4:x887}, so they could also be understood as locatives. In other cases it is used rarely \REF{ex:4:x888}.
Content 1: \gll Yo iiriw \textbf{iinan} \textbf{aasa=pa} karu-owa erup ar-ep me keker op-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM earlier sky canoe=LOC run-NMZ two become-SS.SEQ not fear hold-PA-1s | \glt `I had already travelled by plane twice, and was not afraid.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Sureka}\textbf{=pa} owora nain teek-ap aaw-e-mik. | \gls harvesting.stick=LOC betelnut that1 pluck-SS.SEQ get-PA-1/3p | \glt `They picked the betelnuts with a harvesting stick.'

Knowledge Point: The comitative clitic is also possible but infrequent in instrumental manner phrases \REF{ex:4:x890}. Its use in this function may be influenced by Tok Pisin, where \textstyleForeignWords{wantaim} `together (with)' is used not only for accompaniment, but for instruments as well.
Content 1: \gll Mauwa ar-e-n, \textbf{amia=iya} nenar-e-mik=i? | \gls what become-PA-2s bow/gun=COM shoot.you-PA-1/3p=QM | \glt `What happened to you, did they shoot you with a gun?'
